habitat_description: Sigmodon arizonae primarily inhabits sites with dense herbaceous vegetation (Andersen and Nelson, 1999; Frey et al., 2002; Litt, 2007; Gwinn et al., 2011), particular riparian or other areas near ample water (Andersen and Nelson, 1999; Carelton et al., 1999; Frey et al., 2002; Gwinn et al., 2011). The species is also found in open riparian woodland or shrubland with an herbaceous component (Andersen, 1994; Andersen and Nelson, 1999; Frey et al., 2002), mesquite woodlands (Andersen and Nelson, 1999; Frey et al., 2002), introduced riparian vegetation such as saltcedar (Collins, 1998), and irrigated cropland, particularly near canals or other water sources (Zeiner et al., 1990; Collins, 1998; Gwinn et al., 1999). Arizona cotton rats are noticeably absent from sites until herbaceous vegetation develops (Andersen and Nelson, 1999), and their abundance increases with that of non-native grasses (Litt, 2007).
